item.title: Uploading and Downloading files using Shiny
item.description: When reading interesting books on my Kobo reader, I like to mark some parts of the text. Using those notes later can be difficult because they are stored on your Kobo in a *.annot file. To convert them to a readable *.txt file I made a shiny app. After converting you can you the result on-line and download it if you want. The code can be found here. Uploading a File In shiny you can upload a file using the fileInput() function, that creates an upload control element that can be used to upload files.

item.title: Voting Recommender
item.description: In the Netherlands we have the StemWijzer a tool that calculates for which person to vote depending on your position on some statements. In Colombia they did not have such a tool yet. So I decided to make a template application which can work for any country. The only thing you need is a list of statements where you can agree with or not. And a list of persons of which you know their positions on those statements.

item.title: List of lists of different length to a data frame
item.description: When scraping data from an internet page it is commun that it is not nicely formatted in table kind of way. To me it happens a lot that you get a list of lists and that the second layer of lists have different lengths. To convert this kind of data can be tricky so I made an example here. It is a shiny application that reads data from the eredivisie beach site and uses it to culculate the current standings for the wildcards for the EC.

item.title: Animations in Shiny using TweenLite
item.description: From a colleague I heard about TweenLite, a JavaScript library that can be used to animate objects on your website. You can move elements around by controlling their speed and position. I wanted to see how well this would work in a Shiny application so I experimented a little bit with that. The result is an application that can keep track of the score of the the weakest link, a TV game show from more than 10 years ago.

item.title: Colombian Cooking
item.description: Last December I had the opportunity to work with my friends from randommonkey. We made special about the Colombian kitchen. Part of this special was a Shiny application that can be used to search trough the Colombian recipes. Names, ingredient, region, complexity and the time required can be used to find your favorite one. After finding a recipe you can download the description. So if you are interested in making some Mojarras fritas (and you know a little Spanish because the page is completely in Spanish) look here.
